(Virtual) Flight of the (Nauseated) Navigator
"After sessions in flight simulators, highly trained pilots...get 'simulator sickness': they tend to crash their cars, become nauseated, and so on...[Why] is it that after flying real planes, and seeing roughly the same sorts of images as as in the simulator, pilots do not tend to crash their cars, become sick, and so on?" (David Morris, The Sense of Space, 2004)
While it may be tempting to assume the pilot's disorientation and nausea to be the result of prolonged immersion in a primitively-rendered environment or the effects of navigating an uncanny topology, this answer is too narrow. What it fails to take into account is the interdependent cooperation of the various perceptual systems in the subject's experience and exploration of the environment (See James J. Gibson's excellent The Senses Considered as Perceptual Systems, 1966). Although it's imprudent and perhaps misleading to speak of the subject or her perceptual systems in such monolithic terms, I think in this instance it helps to decompose the traditional presumptions of atomic sensations and clearly defined "senses" or perceptual organs.
Regardless of the level of graphical sophistication in the simulation, the pilot of the virtual aircraft does not have access to the same rich reservoir of perceptual information as can be found in the natural environment. This discontinuity with and alienation from the environment is then experienced as nausea. The pilot may in a limited sense see her virtual environment, but she cannot feel it's full presence from this partial and incomplete data set. As Morris (and Gibson before him) would say, you don't see with your eyes, but with your entire body.
(Image: screenshot from the computer game Microsoft Flight Simulator X)
P.S., if you need to cleanse your palette after this post (or maybe just I do?), then please enjoy this trailer for the fantastic and classic Pee-Wee Herman as an alien spaceship from the future film, Flight of the Navigator: http://youtu.be/XnB7rIL2fy8﻿
